comments:
R3.0 build

- started R3.0 on an old workspace
- shortly after startup, selected several projects and deleted them (yes to
prompt to delete content)
- it failed on a couple of the projects
- log has the following
- note that the first java.lang.Exception is not a real exception: it's just
logged with the multi-status capturing the ResourceExceptions.

The DeleteResourceAction in the workbench just calls IProject.delete, with
force=false.

It's possible some or all of the resources were out of sync, although the error
messages don't give any hint that this is the case.

I'm logging this against CVS since it seems to be complaining about the CVS dirs
in particular, not other resources which may be out of sync.

The problem is that the operation is trying to delete a file or folder that is 
being accessed by another thread. In this case, the thread is probably the CVS 
decorator but it could just as easily be another thread. One solution would be 
for the decorator to obtain a scheduling rule when decorating but this is not 
practical. Since there's really nothing else that could be done about this from 
a CVS standpoint, I'm moving this to Core. 

Possible solutions include a retry on failure or the use of read-locks which 
would allow multiple readers but block writers.

This is a known problem, but we don't seem to have a bug report for it. Ask
Michael summarized, deletion fails on Windows when the file is currently being
read. We would need some sort of read lock to properly detect and handle the
situation.

I've recently gotten the same problem in version 3.0. Not being able to delete 
a file in the Package Explorer, Navigator or Windows Explorer, until I've 
restarted Eclipse. The file is not accessed from any active editors.
The only change I've made to my setup, since before I noticed this rather 
annoying problem, is to install XP SP2 - I cannot see this being the reason...

I've searched bugzilla for the problem, and found the following (sort of 
relevant) bugs:
#73155 - WONTFIX :-(
#72633
#60570
